description.narrative: The project entails constructing a methodology for a self-induced decolonisation process of the Miskito indigenous territories of Twi Waupasa, Twi Yahbra ja Wangki Twi on Northern Atlantic Autonomous Region of Nicaragua, strengthening the administrative an d territorial governance capacity of the implementing organisations AMICA and YATAMA, and production of websites for them. The decolonization process aims to resolve the fate of the non-indigenous population of the indigenous territories and halt further i mmigration in order to materialize the indigenous peoples' legal right to govern their territories, protect their natural resources and improve the indigenous peoples' quality of life. The project is part of a process implemented by the legal and recognize d Miskito leadership (the territorial governments and YATAMA as people's movement) in favour of their communities. AMICA was founded in 1990 by a group of Miskito women repatriated from Honduras to Nicaragua after the war. The community based organisation promotes in particular women’s position within the indigenous territories on the Atlantic Coast of Nicaragua. The themes AMICA works on include human rights, supporting community based ecotourism managed by women, women’s revolving fund, legal assistan ce in cases of domestic violence, supporting youth leadership respecting traditional Miskito values, environmental education and community development based on gender equality. AMICA promotes indigenous leadership. It participates actively in Central Ameri can indigenous women’s networks on domestic violence and biodiversity.
